paragraphs.text: Did Coltrane say 'Allah Supreme'?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: "A Love Supreme" is widely recognised as John Coltrane's masterwork, and a milestone recording in the history of jazz
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Many an aficionado came to jazz through that classic album- a 32-minute-long composition organised around a four-note bass routine
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The manuscript for the album is one of the National Museum of American History's treasures
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the saxophone that Coltrane used to record the piece was recently gifted to the Smithsonian Museum
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: former US President Bill Clinton, a saxophonist and Coltrane fan, is said to have "A Love Supreme" set as the ringtone for when Hillary calls
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This week marks the 50th anniversary of "A Love Supreme"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Recorded on December 9, 1964, the composition is being celebrated worldwide in concerts, festivals, academic symposia and even at churches
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Saint John Coltrane African Orthodox Church - founded in 1969 by two clerics who saw Coltrane perform live in the San Francisco, and experienced a "sound baptism"- celebrated "A Love Supreme" mass on December 8, in San Francisco's iconic Grace Cathedral
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The recording has long been understood to be a deeply spiritual, even devotional, piece
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Its four phases - "Acknowledgement", "Resolution", "Pursuance" and "Psalms" - reflect what Coltrane described as a "spiritual awakening" in his overcoming of drug and alcohol problems
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: All praise belongs to God
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: what was the nature of that "spiritual awakening"?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The conventional view is that by 1964, Coltrane had moved away from his Methodist upbringing, adopting a "pan-religious" outlook with a particular interest in Eastern mysticism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In spite of that
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: "A Love Supreme" is still described as laden with Biblical symbolism: the title "Psalm", and the rising cadences, reminiscent of black preachers' style, are offered as evidence that Coltrane was still rooted in Christianity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: ask one of the jazzmen or Muslim elders who knew Coltrane, and you get a different answer
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The saxophonist Yusef Lateef, who died at the age of 93 earlier this year, worked closely with Coltrane between 1963 and 1966
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In his autobiography , "A Gentle Giant", Lateef says:"The prayer that John wrote in 'A Love Supreme' repeats the phrase 'All praise belongs to God no matter what' several times
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: This phrase has the semantics of the al-Fatiha, which is the first chapter or sura of the Holy Quran
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: The Arabic transliteration is 'al-Humdulilah
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Since all faithful Muslims say the al-Fatiha five times a day or more, it is reasonable to assume that John heard this phrase from [his Muslim wife] Sister Naima many times."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Lateef is referring to the poem Coltrane wrote and included in the liner notes of the album
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Coltrane wrote:"No matter what... It is with God. He is gracious and merciful" and ends with "All praise to God..."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: What Lateef and others have noted is that "gracious and merciful" is a translation of "rahman raheem", the opening lines of the Fatiha
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Moreover
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: say the elders, when Coltrane begins chanting the album's title for half a minute it sounds like a Sufi breathily repeating "Allah supreme"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The relationship between Islam and jazz is almost a century-old
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It was in the 1920s that the Ahmadiyya movement, a heterodox Islamic movement that emerged in 19th century India, began sending missionaries to US cities, building a substantial following among African Americans in the decades to come
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: In a trend that still intrigues historians and music critics, after World War II, scores of jazz musicians embraced Ahmadi Islam
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When Coltrane arrived in Philadelphia in 1943, the Muslim presence in the "city of brotherly love" would rattle the young man
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As he told an interviewer in 1958:"This Muslim thing came up. I got introduced to that. And that kind of shook me."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Ongoing debate in Philadelphia
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The saxophonist was surrounded by Muslims
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: his drummer Rashied Ali was Muslim, as was his pianist McCoy Tyner (Suleiman Saud), and saxophonist Lateef
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Coltrane then married Naima Grubbs, an observant Muslim
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Even Coltrane's band members have pondered his relationship to Islam
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Lateef suspected that Coltrane's art was influenced by the Quran
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the drummer Rashied Ali thought that the saxophonist was "a real country boy" and that "he was into being a Muslim and everything like that"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Back then jazz and Islam were intertwined - the first time I heard the adhan on Temple University radio, I thought it was a Nina Simone song," says Imam Nadim Ali, a celebrated jazz deejay and community leader
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: who spent his youth in Philadelphia
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: "Artists were deeply influenced by Islam - sometimes publicly in their art, sometimes privately."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It's not inconceivable that "A Love Supreme" could have been inspired by the Quran
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: After all
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as the elders will observe,"Celebration", that great funk hit by Kool & the Gang, was inspired by a Quranic sura
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "The initial idea came from the Quran," says Ronald Bell (Khalis Bayyan), the group's saxophonist and musical arranger
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "I was reading the passage, where God was creating Adam, and the angels were celebrating and singing praises
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: That inspired me to write the basic chords, the line, 'Everyone around the world, come on, celebration'."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: This song inspired by Islam - and released in 1980 - would become an international hit heard at ball games and political rallies in the US, and ironically was played by the Reagan administration on February 7, 1981, to welcome home the hostages held by students in the Islamic Republic of Iran
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: One also hears the argument that Coltrane wanted to title his composition "Allah Supreme"- instead of "A Love Supreme" - but was worried about a political backlash, given the ongoing conflict in the Middle East
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The mass conversion of African Americans to Islam unsettled many European Americans and tensions rippled into the jazz world
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Jazz critics would often dismiss the converts as "strange" and "confused"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Young converts
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: In his memoir, Dizzy Gillespie candidly describes the pressures that faced young converts in the jazz world
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "The movement among jazz musicians towards Islam created quite a stir, especially with the surge of the Zionist movement," writes Dizzy Gillespie in"To Be or Not to Bop"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "A lot of friction arose between Jews and Muslims, which took the form of a semi-boycott in New York of jazz musicians with Muslim names... Near the end of the '40s, the newspapers really got worried about whether I'd convert to Islam."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Gillespie was, as he would say,"intrigued" by "the beautiful sound of the word Quran and discussed Islam extensively with Lateef
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: But in 1948, in a shoot for a feature story with Life magazine, Gillespie was asked to pose shirtless, cross-legged, and bowing with his arms outstretched
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The magazine published the piece and claimed (falsely) that the trumpeter was bowing in prayer towards Mecca
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The media ruckus that ensued about the King of Bebop's abandonment of Christianity incensed Gillespie. He would eventually become a Bahai."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Political and racial pressures still bear heavily on black and Muslim artists (especially hip hop artists) today
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And we may never know what Coltrane had in mind when he composed his masterpiece
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as the US celebrates and and tries to mainstream figures from the turbulent 1960s, voices from the communities that produced the likes of Coltrane, Malcolm X and Muhammad Ali, should be heard - especially as the domestic and foreign policies that pushed African Americans towards Islam a century ago are still with us
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Hisham Aidi teaches at Columbia University
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He is the author of the critically acclaimed Rebel Music: Race, Empire and the New Muslim Youth Culture, a study of black internationalism and global youth culture
paragraphs.label: anecdote
